thread.section_title: ACLU of Northern California - Technology and Civil Liberties
thread.title: Speak Out Against Warrantless Digital Surveillance
thread.title_full: Speak Out Against Warrantless Digital Surveillance

author: Catrina Roallos
title: Speak Out Against Warrantless Digital Surveillance
text:
Speak Out Against Warrantless Digital Surveillance Issues : 
Texas, Virginia, Maine, and Utah have updated their privacy laws to require a warrant for digital surveillance. Unfortunately, in California, your email, text messages, and other digital information still aren't protected from warrantless searches. 
4 out of 5 of California voters support requiring a warrant for digital surveillance. 
“Californians want police to get a warrant before accessing private emails, text messages, and tracking cell phones. They want to see a change that makes sure their privacy is properly protected.” —Nicole A. Ozer 
If you agree, add your voice ! When should cops get a warrant?* Before accessing your internet use and what you do online - 82% YES - Latinos (93%) showed the strongest support followed by people ages 18-29 (90%) then African Americans (88%). Before accessing your email - 82% YES Before tracking your cell phone and how you use it - 79% YES - Asians (95%) showed the strongest support followed by African Americans (93%) then people ages 50-64 (82%) and men (82%). Before accessing your text messages - 77% YES 
While government demands for consumer data are on an exponential rise, it's clear that we need to update privacy protections for the modern digital age. You shouldn’t be forced to choose between using technology and keeping your personal life private.
